metadata.case_name: Heirs of Mahant Tokhnarain Puri (Appellant) v. Heirs of Deokinand (Respondents)

facts.text: Deokinand, common ancestor of plaintiff-respondents 1 to 4 and proforma respondents 6 to 12, executed a document dated August 20, 1923, in favour of Mahant Tokhnarain Puri of Nadra, predecessor-in-interest of defendant 1, hypothecating eight annas milkiat share in mauza Lodipur, Mahimabigha, Tauze No. 4246 for Rs. 31,701 debt payable to the Mahanth.

There was a pre-existing thika lease dated April 21, 1922, in favour of Munshi Dodraj Lal alias Munshi Jatadhari Lal, for 9 years, under which Rs. 2,205 was taken as peshgi money without interest and rent fixed at Rs. 2,205.
Respondents claim the 1923 document is a usufructuary mortgage; appellant asserts it is a lease.
Plaintiff-respondents instituted Title Suit No. 4 of 1945 in Court of Additional Subordinate Judge IV, Gaya, for redemption of the document, rendition of accounts, and recovery of surplus profits.
Appellant pleaded the document was a lease, not mortgage; if mortgage, anomalous mortgage with no statutory liability for accounts; if usufructuary, governed by s.77 TPA exempting from s.76(d)(g).

Subordinate Judge, Gaya, held document created usufructuary mortgage, s.77 TPA applied exonerating appellant from accounts; granted conditional decree for possession on deposit of Rs. 26,839-7-0 within six months (judgment/decree dated December 18, 1945).

Plaintiff-respondents appealed to Patna High Court (Appeal from Original Decree No. 188 of 1945); High Court agreed it was usufructuary mortgage but held s.77 TPA inapplicable; set aside Subordinate Judge's decree, passed preliminary decree for redemption and sale on default, directed rendition of accounts (judgment/decree dated December 12, 1950).
Second defendant (appellant) preferred appeal to Supreme Court by certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) of Constitution.

Document (Exhibit A-3) recitals: Executant heavily indebted; friends settled to let out part in ijara at lower interest; total peshgi Rs. 29,496 at 1/2% per month interest + Rs. 2,205 without interest; term 15 years from 1331 to 1345 Fasli; ijara with possession; during thika, realize rent Rs.2,205, set off Rs.1,769-12-0 as interest, pay Rs.435-4-0 as reserved rent; after thika expiry (1338 Fasli), take sir possession, appropriate produce towards interest, pay Rs.435-4-0 rent; no claim on increase in produce; repay Rs.31,701 at end or extend.
Previous mortgage bonds discharged by set-off against peshgi, endorsements made.

legal_issues.text: Whether the 1923 document is a lease or a mortgage.
If a mortgage, whether it is a usufructuary mortgage or an anomalous mortgage.
Whether s.77 of the Transfer of Property Act applies, exempting the mortgagee from liability to render accounts under s.76(g) and (h).

petitioner_arguments.text: The document was a lease, not a mortgage, so suit for redemption not maintainable.
If mortgage, it is anomalous, governed by contract terms, no statutory liability for accounts under s.76 TPA.
If usufructuary mortgage, s.77 TPA applies as mortgagee authorized to take receipts in lieu of interest, exempting from s.76(d)(g).

respondent_arguments.text: The document is a usufructuary mortgage, requiring rendition of accounts.

S.77 TPA does not apply as mortgagee not authorized to take entire receipts in lieu of interest; had to pay Rs.435-4-0 reserved rent, indicating surplus to account for; mention of specified interest rate means only part of receipts towards interest.

court_reasoning.text: Intention of parties governs: debt with land security for redemption makes it mortgage whatever name called. Document terms show debt (Rs.31,701, part with interest), security of 8 annas share, repayment at end, explicit statements of hypothecation and usufructuary mortgage intent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Gist is mortgage, not lease; property given as security for loan.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide usufructuary vs anomalous as result same; under document, mortgagee to appropriate entire receipts towards interest, pay fixed Rs.435-4-0 personally (not from receipts), mortgagor no claim on produce increase.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contract authorizes receipts in lieu of interest.

court_reasoning.text: S.77 TPA applies: contract that receipts taken in lieu of interest (not divided; fixed payment separate personal obligation); mere mention of interest rate does not negate.
Even if anomalous under s.98, contract terms same: no liability for excess receipts accounts.

holdings.text: The document is a mortgage and not a lease.
S.77 TPA applies; mortgagee not liable to render accounts to mortgagor.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pandit Bachchu Lal v. Chaudhri Syed Mohammad Mah
precedents_cited.relevance: Held that mention of interest rate does not prevent s.77 TPA application if contract allows appropriation of receipts/surplus in lieu of interest.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs rights/liabilities of mortgagee in possession; s.77 exempts accounting if receipts taken in lieu of interest; s.98 for anomalous mortgages by contract.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for certificate granting appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside Patna High Court decree directing accounts and preliminary redemption decree; restored Subordinate Judge's conditional decree for possession on deposit of Rs.26,839-7-0 without accounts.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of trial court's decree in favor of appellant (mortgagee) for possession on deposit, no accounts.

key_quotes.text: "the intention of the parties must be looked into and that once you get a debt with security of land for its redemption, then the arrangement is a mortgage by whatever name it is called."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Guiding rule to determine mortgage vs lease.

key_quotes.text: "In security of the payment of the peshgi money with or without interest mentioned in this ijara deed, I, the executant, have mortgaged, hypothecated, encumbered and made liable the ijara property."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explicit declaration in document confirming mortgage intent.

key_quotes.text: "the mortgagee was under a personal obligation to pay Rs. 435-4-0 to the mortgagor and had a right to take the entire receipts from the land in lieu of interest."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes fixed payment from receipts appropriation, applying s.77 TPA.
